case_vignette: A 5-year-old is brought into your office by his mother. His mother states that he is having 10-20 episodes per day where he stops responding to his mother and is found staring out of the window. During these periods, he blinks more frequently than normal, but returns to his normal self afterwards. These episodes last 30 to 60 seconds. His mother states that all of his milestones have been normal and he had an uncomplicated birth. His mother also denies any other recent illness. On exam, his vitals are normal. During one of these episodes in the office, his EEG shows three-per-second spike and wave discharge.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having moments each day where I just stop responding and stare out of the window, and I blink a lot more than usual during these times.
How long do these episodes last?
These episodes last about 30 to 60 seconds.
How long have you been experiencing these episodes?
Sorry, but I can't provide any information on how long I've been experiencing these episodes.
Have you had any previous episodes of altered consciousness or memory lapses in the past?
No, all of my milestones have been normal, and I had an uncomplicated birth.
Have you experienced any other symptoms like confusion, weakness, or changes in speech?
No, I haven't had any other recent illness or symptoms like that.
Has anyone in your family been diagnosed with a neurological condition?
Sorry, but I don't have any information about my family's medical history.
Are you currently taking any medications?
There's no information on whether I'm taking any medications or not.
Have you had any recent head injuries or infections?
No, I haven't had any recent head injuries or infections.
Final Diagnosis: Absence seizures (petit mal seizures).

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient presents to the clinic with episodes of absent staring and increased blinking. The episodes last about 30 to 60 seconds and occur multiple times a day. The patient is unable to provide information on the duration of these episodes. The patient denies any recent illness or symptoms, and has had uncomplicated development and birth history. There is no information on the patient's family medical history or current medications. The patient also denies any recent head injuries or infections.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is childhood absence epilepsy (CAE).

They happen about 10-20 times a day and each lasts for about 30 to 60 seconds.
